thread.title: Buckley back to fill big point guard shoes for Iowa State women
thread.title_full: Buckley back to fill big point guard shoes for Iowa State women

title: Buckley back to fill big point guard shoes for Iowa State women
text:
Buckley back to fill big point guard shoes for Iowa State women Jadda Buckley to start at point guard for Iowa State Post to Facebook Buckley back to fill big point guard shoes for Iowa State women Jadda Buckley to start at point guard for Iowa State Check out this story on desmoinesregister.com: http://dmreg.co/1LkAIoZ Cancel Send A link has been sent to your friend's email address. Posted! A link has been posted to your Facebook feed. 1 To find out more about Facebook commenting please read the Conversation Guidelines and FAQs Buckley back to fill big point guard shoes for Iowa State women Tommy Birch , tbirch@dmreg.com 7:57 a.m. CDT October 9, 2015 Buy Photo TeeTee Starks, Meredith Burkhall, and Bridget Carleton stand for a portrait during media day in Ames Thursday, Oct. 8, 2015. Zach Boyden-Holmes/The Register Fullscreen Buy Photo TeeTee Starks, Meredith Burkhall, and Bridget Carleton stand for a portrait during media day in Ames Thursday, Oct. 8, 2015. Zach Boyden-Holmes/The Register Jadda Buckley stands for a portrait during media day in Ames Thursday, Oct. 8, 2015. Zach Boyden-Holmes/The Register Jadda Buckley stands for a portrait during media day in Ames Thursday, Oct. 8, 2015. Zach Boyden-Holmes/The Register Jadda Buckley stands for a portrait during media day in Ames Thursday, Oct. 8, 2015. Zach Boyden-Holmes/The Register Bridget Carleton stands for a portrait during media day in Ames Thursday, Oct. 8, 2015. Zach Boyden-Holmes/The Register Coach Bill Fennelly speaks during media day in Ames Thursday, Oct. 8, 2015. Zach Boyden-Holmes/The Register Like this topic? You may also like these photo galleries: Replay Jadda Buckley stands for a portrait during media day in Ames Thursday, Oct. 8, 2015. (Photo: Zach Boyden-Holmes/The Register) Buy Photo 111 CONNECT 15 TWEET LINKEDIN 1 COMMENT EMAIL MORE 
AMES, Ia. — Iowa State guard Jadda Buckley consistently walks in a room at the team’s practice facility full of pictures of former Cyclone players who were drafted by WNBA teams. 
Among them is a collection of some of the greatest point guards in school history. As Iowa State’s newest point guard, Buckley is aiming to add her picture to the elite list. 
Buckley will have big shoes to fill as she takes over as the starting point guard this season. 
“It’s her job right now and it’s her team to lead and I have great confidence she can do that,” coach Bill Fennelly said during the team's media day Thursday afternoon. 
Buckley, a 5-foot-8, redshirt sophomore, will take over for Nikki Moody, who finished her career at Iowa State as one of the best point guards in school history. Moody, a four-year starter, averaged 14.5 points and 6.8 assists per game last season and became Iowa State’s all-time assists leader. 
"This is the first year in a long time where we don't have an incumbent point guard that you know is really, really good," Fennelly said. 
With Moody now gone, the attention now shifts to Buckley, a guard who has played on and off the ball at times during her Iowa State career. The Mason City native burst onto the scene during the 2013-14 campaign when she averaged 10.9 points, 3.3 assists, and 2.3 rebounds in 31 games, including 28 starts, as a freshman. 
Any hopes of an encore the following season were shut down when Buckley was shut down after nine games due to a stress injury in her right foot. Buckley, who averaged 9.4 points, 2.8 rebounds, and 2.3 assists while she was playing, received a medical redshirt for the season. 
The season was full of trials and tribulations for Buckley who dealt with the physical pain of the injury as well as the mental demons of not being able to play. 
“I think a big thing was coaches and coach Fennelly telling me to look at the bigger picture,” Buckley said. “For me, I was only focusing on that season or that Saturday’s game.” 
The picture is now clear for Buckley, who is healthy and ready to roll in her new role. In fact, those pictures of the players that she passes by routinely have become an inspiration for her. 
“He (Fennelly) always brings up in practice and in games stuff like that, things that they did and that’s something you want to live up to because they left a legacy so you want to leave a legacy, too,” Buckley said. 
The idea that Buckley’s picture could end up on the wall isn’t out of the question. 
“If you look at that wall in there, it’s full of great point guards and I honestly believe Jadda Buckley could be the next one,” Fennelly said. 
Time will tell. But, so far, the move has gone well. 
“She’s bought into it,” said Iowa State guard Seanna Johnson. “She’s been doing pretty good in practice.” 
Buckley credits watching Moody as a learning experience. She said Moody’s ability to adjust on the fly is one of the big things she took away. 
“Plays break down during games so you have to go to other options and I think that was something that she was very strong in and that’s where I learned from her a lot,” Buckley said. 
Buckley realizes that there is still lots to learn. But she understands what her coaches were talking about when they told her to see the bigger picture when she was hurt. 
“I have a lot of work ahead of me, though, and I have a lot of basketball knowledge that I need to intake to get on one of those walls and next to one of those other girls but it’s always a dream,” Buckley said. “You’ve always got to dream.” 
BREAKING DOWN THE CYCLONES 
Coach : Bill Fennelly, 600-259 overall, 166-53 at Iowa State 
Last season : 18-13 (9-9 in conference), lost in opening round of the Big 12 Conference Tournament and opening round of the NCAA Tournament. 
Key departures : Nikki Moody (14.5 points per game, 6.8 assists per game), Brynn Williamson (11.6 ppg., 1.0 apg., and 6.3 rpg), and Fallon Ellis (5.2 ppg., 1.1 apg., and 4.2 rpg.). 
Key newcomers : Bridget Carleton (Chatham, Ontario, Canada), TeeTee Starks (Brooklyn Park, Minn.), and Meredith Burkhall (Des Moines). 
2015-16 SCHEDULE 
November— 5: vs. Midwestern State (exhibition); 8: vs. Concordia St. Paul (exhibition); 13: vs. Hampton; 15: at Drake; 22: vs. New Orleans; 26: vs. Texas State (at Cancun Challenge); 27: vs. Duke (at Cancun Challenge); 28: vs. Idaho (at Cancun Challenge). 
December —2: at Northern Iowa; 6: vs. Southern; 11: vs. Iowa; 13: vs. Arkansas-Pine Bluff; 20: vs. Alcorn State; 22: vs. Northern Arizona; 30: at Kansas State. 
January —2: vs. Oklahoma State; 6: at Texas; 9: vs. Kansas; 17: at Texas Tech; 20: at Oklahoma State; 23: vs. Baylor; 27: vs. Texas Christian; 30: vs. Oklahoma. 
February —2: at Kansas; 6: vs. Texas; 10: at West Virginia; 13: at Texas Christian; 17: vs. Texas Tech; 20: at Baylor; 24: vs. Kansas State; 27: at Oklahoma. 
March —1: vs. West Virginia; 4-7: Big 12 Conference Tournament at Oklahoma City, OKla. 
IOWA STATE WOMEN’S ROSTER 
Lexi Albrecht (5-10, jr.). Carroll native who saw limited action over the last two seasons, appearing in 20 games. Scored a career-high six points against Howard last season. 
Madison Baier (6-4, sr.). Played in 26 games last season after suffering a season-ending torn ACL during the 2013-2014 season. Scored 18 points, grabbed 24 rebounds, and blocked six shots last season. 
Kidd Blaskowsky (5-7, sr.) Lethal long distance shooter who drained three or more 3-pointers in 10 games last season. Blaskowsky appeared in all 31 games during the 2014-2015 season, earning 24 starts. She averaged 7.7 points and 4.1 rebounds per game. 
Jadda Buckley (5-8, redshirt soph.) Had a stellar start as a freshman in 2013-2014 averaging 10.9 points, 3.3 assists, and 2.3 rebounds. Buckley’s second season was limited to just nine games due to a stress injury in her right foot that caused her to be shut down. She secured a medical redshirt and will replace Nikki Moody at the point guard position. 
Meredith Burkhall (6-3, fr.). Rated the top prospect out of Iowa by ProspectsNation.com and named the Class 5-A Player of the Year. Burkhall averaged 16.0 points throughout her high school career and finished with a school-record 1,422 points and 755 rebounds at Des Moines Roosevelt. 
Bridget Carleton (6-1, fr.) Competed for Canada Basketball on their U16, U18, and U19 teams. Averaged 12.3 points in 27 international games for Canada. Carleton, Iowa State’s first women’s basketball recruit from Canada, averaged 28.4 points, 11.1 rebounds, 3.1 steals, and 2.8 assists her senior year playing club basketball. Fennelly said if the Cyclones had a game now, Carleton would start. 
Emily Durr (6-0, so.) Played in all 31 games as freshman, averaging 4.8 points and 2.1 rebounds last season. Durr scored in double figured four times and grabbed five or more rebounds in five games last season. Sharpshooter also shot 29-32 from the free throw line. 
Bryanna Fernstrom (5-6, so.) Center finished her first season with 36 blocks — the second-most in school history among freshmen. Fernstrom’s up and down season ended with her averaging 9.0 points, 3.2 rebounds, and 1.2 blocks per game in 31 appearances, including 25 starts. 
Jordan Jensen (6-2, jr.) Saw limited action her first two seasons appearing in 18 total games. Jensen scored four points, grabbed seven rebounds, and handed out two assists last season. 
Seanna Johnson (5-10, jr.) Rebounding machine who became the fastest Cyclone to reach 500 career rebounds in just 59 games. Johnson also led the Big 12 in rebounding averaging 9.2 per game. She also finished second on the team in scoring averaging 11.7 points per game last season. 
Claire Ricketts (6-3, redshirt fr.) Received a medical redshirt after going down with a season-ending injury after seeing action in just three games her first season. Ricketts will add some height. 
TeeTee Starks (5-9, fr.) The top prospect in Minnesota according to 5 State Hoops. Starks netted over 1,000 career points in high school and helped her team to three state title. 111 CONNECT 15 TWEET LINKEDIN 1 COMMENT EMAIL MORE Read or Share this story: http://dmreg.co/1LkAIoZ TOP VIDEOS
